text: Murder – If someone intentionally takes another person's life, they can be punished with death or life imprisonment. It’s one of the most serious offences under the IPC and may also include a fine.
Culpable homicide not amounting to murder – This applies when a person causes death but without the intention to murder. The punishment can be life imprisonment or up to ten years with a fine.

Attempt to murder – If someone tries to kill another person but fails, they can still be punished. The punishment can go up to ten years and fine, and if hurt is caused, it may extend to life imprisonment.
Attempt to commit culpable homicide – When a person does something that could cause death but without intent to murder, they can be jailed up to three years, fined, or both.
Attempt to commit suicide – Anyone who tries to take their own life may be punished with simple imprisonment up to one year or fine, or both.
Definition of thug – A thug is someone who habitually robs or kills people, often by violence or strangulation. It’s a serious criminal identity under the IPC.
Causing miscarriage – If someone intentionally causes a woman to miscarry (with her consent), it’s punishable by up to three years of imprisonment and a fine.
Causing miscarriage without a woman’s consent – This is a grave offence, punishable by imprisonment for life or up to ten years along with a fine.
Act done to prevent child being born alive – If someone intentionally acts to prevent a baby from being born alive or causes its death after birth, the punishment can be up to ten years and fine.
Causing death of unborn child – If an act results in the death of an unborn child in the womb (a ‘quick’ child), the offender may face up to ten years in prison and a fine.
Definition of hurt – Any action that causes bodily pain, disease, or weakness in another person is considered ‘hurt’ under IPC.
Definition of grievous hurt – This includes serious injuries like loss of eyesight, hearing, limb, or permanent disfigurement.
Voluntarily causing hurt – Hurting someone intentionally can lead to imprisonment up to one year, a fine up to one thousand rupees, or both.
Voluntarily causing grievous hurt – Causing serious injury to someone can lead to imprisonment up to seven years and a fine.
Causing grievous hurt with dangerous weapons – Using weapons or harmful means to injure another person can result in life imprisonment or up to ten years and a fine.
Causing hurt to extort confession – If someone inflicts pain to force a confession or information, they can be imprisoned up to ten years and fined.
Wrongful restraint – Stopping someone from moving freely without legal justification can lead to simple imprisonment up to one month or a fine up to five hundred rupees, or both.
Wrongful confinement – Unlawfully restricting someone’s movement within certain boundaries can lead to imprisonment up to one year or a fine up to one thousand rupees, or both.
Punishment for wrongful confinement – Keeping someone locked or detained illegally can lead to imprisonment up to one year or a fine up to one thousand rupees, or both.
Wrongful confinement for three or more days – If someone is confined for three or more days unlawfully, the punishment can be imprisonment up to two years and fine.
Wrongful confinement to extort property – Detaining someone to make them hand over money or valuables is punishable with up to three years in prison and fine.
Definition of assault – Any act that causes another person to fear immediate use of force counts as assault. Even raising a hand can be considered assault if it creates fear.
Assault or criminal force without grave provocation – Using force on someone without strong reason can lead to imprisonment up to three months, a fine up to five hundred rupees, or both.

Assault or criminal force on a woman with intent to outrage her modesty – This means physically assaulting or using criminal force on a woman to insult her dignity. Punishable by up to two years in prison, fine, or both.
Sexual harassment – Includes unwelcome physical contact, sexual comments, or advances. Punishment ranges from one to three years imprisonment or fine, depending on the act.
Assault with intent to disrobe a woman – If someone attacks or uses force to remove a woman’s clothing, they face imprisonment between three to seven years and a fine.

Voyeurism – Watching, photographing, or recording a woman during private acts without her consent is punishable with imprisonment up to three years for the first offence and five years for repeat offences.
Stalking – Following a woman repeatedly or contacting her despite disinterest is punishable with imprisonment up to three years and fine for the first offence, and up to five years for repetition.
text
Kidnapping – Taking or enticing a person away from lawful guardianship without permission is kidnapping. It is punishable with imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
Kidnapping or abducting in order to murder – If someone kidnaps a person with the intent to kill them, they can face life imprisonment or imprisonment up to ten years and fine.
Kidnapping or inducing a woman to compel her marriage – Forcing or deceiving a woman into marriage or illicit relations is punishable with imprisonment up to ten years and fine.
Concealing or keeping a kidnapped person – Anyone who hides or confines a kidnapped person knowing they’ve been kidnapped can be imprisoned up to seven years and fined.

Trafficking of persons – Involves recruitment or transportation of people for exploitation, often through force or deceit. Punishable with imprisonment not less than seven years, which may extend to ten years and fine.
Habitual dealing in slaves – Anyone involved in buying or selling humans as slaves can face life imprisonment or up to ten years and fine.
Theft – If someone dishonestly takes another person’s property without consent, it is theft. Punishable with imprisonment up to three years or fine, or both.
Theft in dwelling house – Committing theft in a house, tent, or vessel is a serious offence with punishment up to seven years and fine.
Theft by clerk or servant – If a servant or employee steals property belonging to their master, they can be imprisoned up to seven years and fined.
Theft with preparation for causing harm – If someone prepares to harm or kill during a theft, punishment can extend up to ten years and fine.
Robbery – When theft or extortion involves violence or threat of violence, it becomes robbery. It’s a more severe form of theft.
Punishment for robbery – The offender can face imprisonment up to ten years and fine. If robbery occurs on a highway at night, punishment may be extended.
Voluntarily causing hurt while committing robbery – If someone hurts another person while committing robbery, they can face life imprisonment or up to ten years and fine.
Dacoity – When five or more people jointly commit or attempt to commit robbery, it is called dacoity. Punishable with life imprisonment or up to ten years and fine.
Robbery or dacoity with attempt to cause death or grievous hurt – If the offender uses a deadly weapon or causes severe injury, punishment is not less than seven years.
Making preparation to commit dacoity – Planning or preparing for a dacoity itself is a serious crime, punishable with imprisonment up to ten years and fine.
Dishonest misappropriation of property – If someone takes or uses another person’s property dishonestly for their own use, they can be punished with imprisonment up to two years, fine, or both.
text
Criminal breach of trust – When a person entrusted with property dishonestly uses it for their own benefit, it is a breach of trust. Punishable with imprisonment up to three years, fine, or both.
Criminal breach of trust by public servant or banker – If a public servant or banker misuses entrusted property, punishment can extend to life imprisonment or up to ten years and fine.
Cheating – Deceiving someone to gain property or make them act against their interest is cheating. It is punishable with imprisonment up to one year, fine, or both.
Cheating by personation – Pretending to be another person to cheat is punishable with imprisonment up to three years, fine, or both.
Cheating and dishonestly inducing delivery of property – If a person cheats someone to obtain money or property, punishment can extend to seven years and fine.
Mischief – Intentionally destroying or damaging another’s property is mischief. Punishable with imprisonment up to three months or fine, or both.
Punishment for mischief – Causing minor damage or loss through mischief can lead to imprisonment up to three months or fine up to five hundred rupees, or both.
Mischief causing damage of fifty rupees or more – Causing major property damage (over ₹50) is punishable with imprisonment up to two years or fine, or both.
Criminal trespass – Entering another person’s property with intent to commit an offence or to insult or annoy is criminal trespass.
Punishment for criminal trespass – Punishable with imprisonment up to three months or fine up to five hundred rupees, or both.
House-trespass – Unlawfully entering someone’s house is house-trespass. Punishable with imprisonment up to one year or fine up to one thousand rupees, or both.
House-trespass to commit an offence – Entering a home to commit another offence can lead to imprisonment up to two years and fine.
Forgery – Creating a false document with intent to cheat or harm someone’s rights is forgery. It can lead to imprisonment up to two years or fine, or both.
Punishment for forgery – Making or using fake documents is punishable with imprisonment up to two years or fine, or both.
Forgery for purpose of cheating – If forgery is done to cheat someone, punishment extends up to seven years and fine.
Using a forged document as genuine – Using a fake document knowingly is punishable as if the person had made the forgery themselves.
Defamation – Making or publishing false statements that harm a person’s reputation is defamation. It is a serious offence under Indian law.
Punishment for defamation – Anyone found guilty can be imprisoned up to two years or fined, or both.
text
Punishment for defamation – If a person is found guilty of defaming someone, they can be punished with simple imprisonment up to two years, or fined, or both.
Printing or engraving defamatory matter – Anyone who prints or publishes material that defames another person can face imprisonment up to two years or fine, or both.
Criminal intimidation – Threatening another person to cause fear or force them to act against their will is criminal intimidation.
Intentional insult to provoke breach of peace – If a person deliberately insults someone to cause them to lose control or fight, it is punishable by imprisonment up to two years or fine, or both.

Statements leading to public mischief – Making false or alarming statements that can cause fear, violence, or disturbance among people is punishable by imprisonment up to three years or fine, or both.
Punishment for criminal intimidation – If someone threatens another person with injury to their life, property, or reputation, punishment may include imprisonment up to two years, fine, or both.
Criminal intimidation by anonymous communication – Threatening someone without revealing identity is punishable with imprisonment up to two years in addition to other punishments.
Word, gesture or act intended to insult the modesty of a woman – Saying or doing anything to insult a woman’s modesty or privacy can lead to simple imprisonment up to one year, or fine, or both.
Misconduct in public by a drunken person – Behaving indecently in public while drunk is punishable with simple imprisonment up to 24 hours or fine up to ten rupees, or both.

Attempting to commit offences punishable with life imprisonment or other severe punishments – Even an attempt to commit a serious offence can result in half the punishment prescribed for that offence.
Acts done by several persons in furtherance of common intention – When multiple people act together with a shared intent to commit an offence, each is held equally responsible.

Criminal conspiracy – When two or more people agree to commit a crime, it is considered a conspiracy, even if the act is not completed. Punishable with imprisonment depending on the severity of the crime.
Unlawful assembly – When five or more people gather with the intent to commit an offence or disturb peace, it is called unlawful assembly.
Rioting – When unlawful assembly members use force or violence, it becomes rioting. Punishable with imprisonment up to two years or fine, or both.
Promoting enmity between groups – Spreading hatred between different religions, castes, or communities is punishable with imprisonment up to three years or fine, or both.
Public nuisance – Doing any act that causes danger, annoyance, or harm to the public is a public nuisance.
Negligent act likely to spread infection – Carelessly doing something that spreads disease dangerous to life is punishable with imprisonment up to six months or fine, or both.
Malignant act likely to spread infection – Intentionally spreading infectious disease is punishable with imprisonment up to two years or fine, or both.
Negligent conduct with respect to fire or combustible matter – Carelessly handling fire or fuel leading to danger is punishable with imprisonment up to six months or fine, or both.
Causing death by negligence – If someone’s careless act leads to another person’s death, they may be punished with imprisonment up to two years or fine, or both.
Cyber harassment of women – Using digital means to harass or insult women’s dignity is a punishable offence under modern cyber laws linked to IPC 509.
